title: Does Nebraska Men’s Baskebtall Shoot Better Behind the 3 Point Line on their Home Court?
text:
For the last five seasons, only 1 of 5 have ended with a winning record and that was back in the 2018-2019 season. For the next four seasons, the best record they have had was when they went 16-16 last season. It seems Nebraska’s men’s basketball team shoots way better when they play at home compared to when they’re away. Is it their home atmosphere or just the familiarity of PBA? Let’s see if numbers can back up this idea.
Sports Reference is a sports statistics website that provides the shooting percentages over each of the last five seasons. You can see the percentages of overall shots, free throws, and three-pointers. Within the data, it is easy to calculate Nebraska and the rest of college basketball’s shooting averages while differentiating the home and away games. To determine whether there is a clear answer about where the Husker’s shoot best, let’s look at Nebraska’s home and away shooting percentages from the last 5 seasons.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(gt)

men2019 <-read_csv("neb.2019.csv")
men2020 <-read_csv("neb.2020.csv")
men2021 <-read_csv("neb.2021.csv")
men2022 <-read_csv("neb.2022.csv")
men2023 <-read_csv("neb.2023.csv")

men <- bind_rows(men2019,men2020,men2021, men2022, men2023)

menthrees <- men |> 
  group_by(Location, Year) |> 
  summarize(
    Average3PPct = mean(ThreePpct)
  )
mentwos <- men |> 
  group_by(Location, Year) |> 
  summarize(
    AverageFGpct = mean(FGpct)
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data = menthrees, aes(x = Year, y = Average3PPct, color = Location, group=Location)) +
  labs(
    title = "Nebraska shoots better with the home court advantage",
    subtitle = "1 out of the 5 last seasons their 3P% on the road is worse",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Averages",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Nevaeh Stauffer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "red", size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "black", size = 12, face = "bold")
  )





Nebraska has shot significantly better on their home court behind the three point line for 4 out of the 5 past seasons. During the 2021-2022 season the away percentage was better but not by much.
Now let’s compare the same data about Nebraska’s last five seasons to the rest of the teams in the Big 10 and see where they stand.


Code
logs23 <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/logs23.csv")
logs22 <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/logs22.csv")
logs21 <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/logs21.csv") 
logs20 <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/logs20.csv") |> 
  rename(Season = season, TeamFull=Team)
logs19 <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/logs19.csv") |> 
  rename(Season = season, TeamFull=Team)

logs <- bind_rows(logs23, logs22, logs21, logs20, logs19) |> 
  mutate(
    Location = case_when(
      is.na(HomeAway) == TRUE ~ "Home",
      HomeAway == "@" ~ "Away",
      HomeAway == "N" ~ "Neutral"
    )
  )

homeawaylogs <- logs |> 
  group_by(TeamFull, Conference, Season, Location) |>
  summarize(
    Average3PPct = mean(Team3PPCT, na.rm=TRUE)
  ) |> 
  mutate(TeamLocation = paste(TeamFull, Location))

big10away <- homeawaylogs |>
  filter(str_trim(Conference) == "Big Ten") |> 
  filter(Location == "Away")


big10home <- homeawaylogs |>
  filter(str_trim(Conference) == "Big Ten") |> 
  filter(Location == "Home")

nuhome <- big10home |> 
  filter(TeamFull == "Nebraska Cornhuskers")
nuaway <- big10away |> 
  filter(TeamFull == "Nebraska Cornhuskers")
  
menaway <- menthrees |> 
  group_by(Location, Year) |> 
  filter(Location == "Away")

menhome <- menthrees |> 
  group_by(Location, Year) |> 
  filter(Location == "Home") 

ggplot() +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=big10home, 
    aes(x=Average3PPct, y=Season), color="darkblue", alpha=.3) +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=big10away, 
    aes(x=Average3PPct, y=Season), color="blue", alpha=.3) +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=nuhome, 
    aes(x=Average3PPct, y=Season), color="red") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=nuaway, 
    aes(x=Average3PPct, y=Season), color="darkred") +
  geom_text_repel(data=nuhome, 
    aes(x=Average3PPct, y=Season, label=TeamLocation)) + 
  labs(
    title = "Nebraska's 3 Point shooting is just average ",
    subtitle = "Comparing the Huskers to the Big Ten, Nebraska is in the middle",
    x = "Averages",
    y = "Season",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Nevaeh Stauffer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()+
    theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "red", size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "black", size = 12, face = "bold")
  )





So we know that Nebraska shoots better behind the arc with the home court advantage. But compared to the rest of the Big Ten, those percentages still aren’t great and are just about average. Now let’s see if Nebraska’s best home shooting percentages rank in the top 10 in the Big Ten over the past five seasons.


Code
big10home |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  top_n(10, wt=Average3PPct) |> 
  arrange(desc(Average3PPct)) |>
  select(TeamFull, Season, Average3PPct) |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    Average3PPct = "Percentage"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Behind the arc isn't where the Huskers are most likely to dominate",
    subtitle = "Nebraska's best 3 Point Percentage doesn't even rank in the Top 10"
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Nevaeh Stauffer  |  **Source:** Sports Reference")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
    fmt_percent(
    columns = Average3PPct,
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = Average3PPct,
      rows = Average3PPct > .398)
  )






  
    
      Behind the arc isn't where the Huskers are most likely to dominate
    
    
      Nebraska's best 3 Point Percentage doesn't even rank in the Top 10
    
    
      Team
      Season
      Percentage
    
  
  
    Michigan State Spartans
2022-2023
42.0%
    Purdue Boilermakers
2021-2022
40.7%
    Penn State Nittany Lions
2022-2023
40.4%
    Wisconsin Badgers
2020-2021
40.3%
    Ohio State Buckeyes
2019-2020
40.3%
    Michigan Wolverines
2020-2021
40.0%
    Purdue Boilermakers
2018-2019
39.5%
    Iowa Hawkeyes
2020-2021
39.4%
    Iowa Hawkeyes
2022-2023
39.3%
    Michigan State Spartans
2021-2022
39.1%
  
  
    
      By: Nevaeh Stauffer  |  Source: Sports Reference
    
  
  




Over the course of the past 5 seasons, Nebraska’s best at home shooting percentage doesn’t even rank in the top 10.
So Nebraska has had some great individual shooters on their team but as a team, behind the three point line isn’t where you are gonna see them perform at their best abilities.

title: Which Big-Ten Team Had the Most Effective Bench Player’s Last Season?
text:
The Big Ten Conference this past season was full of intense competition and each team held a lot of talent. The conference was led by Purdue who went 29-6 on the season and 15-5 in conference play.
A lot of different things can contribute to a team’s success. Whether it’s points, assists or whatever. But another aspect to think about is who is making these things happen. Depth on your team can be helpful so which one of these Big Ten teams utilized their bench players the most?
Sports Reference is a sports statistics website that provides the statistics for all players on the roster.It provides the minutes played, every shot attempted and made, steals, assists and lots more. By using these resources, it is easy to determine which team had the most depth.
The first question is, what team had the most minutes played by bench players?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

illinois <- read_csv("illinois2023.csv")
indiana <- read_csv("indiana2023.csv")
iowa <- read_csv("iowa2023.csv")
maryland <- read_csv("maryland2023.csv")
michiganS <- read_csv("michigan-state2023.csv")
michigan <- read_csv("michigan2023.csv")
minnesota <- read_csv("minnesota2023.csv")
nebraska <- read_csv("nebraska2023.csv")
north <- read_csv("northwestern2023.csv")
ohio <- read_csv("ohio2023.csv")
penn <- read_csv("penn-state2023.csv")
purdue <- read_csv("purdue2023.csv")
rutgers <- read_csv("rutgers2023.csv")
wisconsin <- read_csv("wisconsin2023 .csv")

bigdancelist <- c("Purdue", "Michigan State", "Illinois", "Iowa", "Maryland", "Indiana", "Northwestern","Penn" )

bigten <- bind_rows(illinois, indiana, iowa, maryland, michiganS, michigan, minnesota, nebraska, north, ohio, penn,purdue, rutgers, wisconsin) 
 
 minutes <- bigten |>
  filter(str_trim(Starter) == "B") |>   
  group_by(Team) |>
   summarize(
     MP = sum(MP)
   ) 

 danceminutes <- minutes |>
   filter(Team %in% bigdancelist)

stats <- bigten |> 
  filter(Starter == "B") |>
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarise(
    avOrebounds = mean(ORB),
    avDrebounds = mean(DRB),
    avsteals = mean(STL),
    avassists = mean(AST)
  ) |>
  select(Team, avOrebounds, avDrebounds, avsteals, avassists)

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=minutes, aes(x=reorder(Team, MP), weight=MP), fill="lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=danceminutes, aes(x=reorder(Team, MP), weight=MP), fill="blue") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    title = "Nebrask",
    subtitle = "Chatter",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Minutes Played",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Nevaeh Stauffer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Nebraska's bench had the most minutes played",
    subtitle = "They had over 2600 bench minutes while the next closest was Ohio State at 2400 ",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Minutes Played",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Nevaeh Stauffer"
    ) +
theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "black", size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "black", size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





All of the teams have utilized their roster as all of the teams have around 2,000 minutes played for their non-starters. Nebraska led the Big Ten in their bench players minutes played while Maryland was the team who utilized their bench the least. But Maryland made the NCAA tournament.
So while teams like Nebraska had the most bench player minutes, did these players do enough on the court to be useful to their teams?


Code
pointsstacked <- bigten |> 
  filter(Starter == "B") |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarize(
    TotalTwos = sum(`2P`),
    TotalThrees = sum(`3P`),
    FreeThrows = sum(FT)
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    Twos = TotalTwos*2,
    Threes = TotalThrees*3
  ) |> 
  select(Team, Twos, Threes, FreeThrows) |> 
  pivot_longer(cols=-Team, names_to="Type", values_to = "Points")

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=pointsstacked, aes(x = reorder(Team, Points), weight=Points, fill=Type)) + 
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    title = "Nebraska led in points scored by their bench",
    subtitle = "The huskers combined for the most two-pointers, three-pointers and free throws scored",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Points Scored",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Nevaeh Stauffer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "black", size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "black", size = 10),
     plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Just like in minutes played, Nebraska led the Big Ten last season for the most points scored by non-starting players. Rutgers, Iowa and Indiana weren’t too far behind.
Now what about rebounding? Which team’s bench players were most helpful on the boards?


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=stats, 
   aes(y=reorder(Team, avDrebounds), x=avDrebounds, xend=avOrebounds),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "blue",
    colour_xend = "black") + 
  labs(
    title = "Minnesota led in offensive and defensive rebounds",
    subtitle = "Their bench's defensive rebounds was significantly higher than any other team",
    x = "Offensive and Defensive Rebounds",
    y = "Team",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Nevaeh Stauffer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "black", size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "black", size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Minnesota, Nebraska and Ohio State were teams that consistently ranked towards the top of the charts in minutes played, points scored and rebounds on the offensive and defensive sides. They were the top 3 teams that had the most depth and utilized it. What is interesting about that is that none of them made the NCAA tournament. So is depth helpful or
